Press Release 27.12.2016 At the December 27, 2016 meeting, the Board of the CBA decided to reduce the Refinancing Rate by 0.25 pp, setting it at 6.25%. Inflation in November was 1.0% compared with 0.6% of inflation in the same month of the previous year, and the 12-month deflation rate continued reducing to 0.6%. According to the CBA estimates, the deflationary environment will persist in the forthcoming months. A slow pace of global economic growth persisted while some inflationary patterns were observable in international commodity markets. The CBA Board estimates that significant inflationary effects from the external sector are not yet likely in the upcoming months. However, there are some inflationary risks related to the raising of the policy rate by the US Federal Reserve and how it would affect the developing countries. The CBA Board notes that economic activity continues to slow down mainly due to supply factors, such as more-than-expected decline in the agricultural sector. On the other hand, the domestic demand has been rebounding largely thanks to the expansionary monetary and fiscal policies implemented in 2015-2016. Yet, some deflationary risks outlined in the fourth quarter's monetary policy program, including a decline in inflation expectations and anticipated reduction in electricity tariff in February, are materializing. This makes persistence of inflation within the lower bound of the confidence band most likely for 2017. In this case, the CBA Board considers it reasonable to loosen monetary conditions for another time. The CBA Board believes that implemented monetary policy has triggered sufficient incentives to overcome the deflationary environment in 2017 and fulfil the inflation target in the forecast horizon. The CBA Board estimates that interest rates have reduced substantially while conventional monetary policy capabilities are now limited. Yet, the CBA remains committed to its primary goal of ensuring price stability and, if necessary, it will react accordingly by using its toolkit to fulfil the inflation target in the medium term. More information on the setting of interest rate will be available in Press Release (Minutes on Interest Rate) due on January 13, 2017. Press Service of the CBA.

Central Bank of Egypt Press Release December 29, 2016 In its meeting held on December 29, 2016, the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) decided to keep the overnight deposit rate, overnight lending rate, and the rate of the Central Bank of Egypt's (CBE) main operation unchanged at 1475 percent, 1575 percent, and 1525 percent, respectivel. The discount rate was also kept unchanged at 1525 percen. Annual headline inflation rose to 1943 percent in November 2016 from 1356 percent in October 2016, as the monthly rate increased to 485 percent in November from 170 percent in Octobe. Consumer prices during November were strongly impacted by the economic reform measures related to the foreign exchange rate market liberalization as well as the hydrocarbon subsidies adjustmen. The bulk of the monthly increase occurred due to core items, particularly food and retail, which came in addition to higher regulated price. Consequently annual core inflation rose to 2073 percent in November 2016 from 1572 percent in October 2016, while the monthly rate rose to 533 percent in November from 281 percent in Octobe. In the meantime, annual real GDP maintained a steady pace of growth during 2015/16, registering 43 percent compared 44 percent in 2014/1. Labor market data show that the unemployment rate narrowed to 125 percent in the quarter ending June 2016 after peaking at 134 percent in the quarter ending December 2013, which coincided with lower real unit labor costs since 201. The unemployment rate inched up to 126 percent in the quarter ending September 201. Developments in the external environment show that there has been some firming of international commodity prices, while low global inflation and subdued global growth maintain weak pressures on domestic prices, respectivel. From the monetary perspective, broad and reserve money growth are likely to be impacted going forward by the phasing out of monetary financing of the fiscal deficit as well as by relatively higher foreign reserves accumulatio. Moreover broad money growth is strongly affected by the revaluation effects of its foreign currency component. Looking ahead, annual inflation is expected to narrow after being impacted by transitory cost- push factors stemming from the economic reform measure. The MPC had acted preemptively in its extraordinary meeting on November 3, 2016 by raising the key CBE rates 300 basis points in anticipation of the inflationary pressure. At this juncture and given the balance of risks, the MPC judges that the key CBE rates are currently appropriat. The MPC reiterates its price stability mandate and will continue to closely monitor all economic and monetary developments, and will not hesitate to adjust the key CBE rates to ensure price stability over the medium-ter.
